maml:description.maml:para: Add a domain FQDN to an LDAP directory path as the server address so the new path can be used for remote queries

Uses RegEx to: - Match the Domain Components from the Distinguished Name in the LDAP directory path - Convert the Domain Components to an FQDN - Insert them into the directory path as the server address
Incomplete LDAP directory path containing a distinguishedName but lacking a server address
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
Incomplete LDAP directory path containing a distinguishedName but lacking a server address

dev:type.maml:name: [System.String] Complete LDAP directory path including server address

dev:remarks.maml:para: Completes the partial LDAP path 'LDAP://CN=user1,OU=UsersOU,DC=ad,DC=contoso,DC=com' to 'LDAP://ad.contoso.com/CN=user1,OU=UsersOU,DC=ad,DC=contoso,DC=com' with the domain FQDN added as the server address. This is crucial for making remote LDAP queries to specific domain controllers, especially when working in multi-domain environments or when connecting to trusted domains.

maml:description.maml:para: Add some useful properties to a DirectoryEntry object for easier access
Add SidString, Domain, and SamAccountName NoteProperties to a DirectoryEntry
Expecting a [System.DirectoryServices.DirectoryEntry] from the LDAP or WinNT providers, or a [PSCustomObject] imitation from Get-DirectoryEntry. Must contain the objectSid property
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
Expecting a [System.DirectoryServices.DirectoryEntry] from the LDAP or WinNT providers, or a [PSCustomObject] imitation from Get-DirectoryEntry. Must contain the objectSid property

dev:type.maml:name: [System.DirectoryServices.DirectoryEntry] or a [PSCustomObject] imitation. InputObject parameter. Must contain the objectSid property.
[System.DirectoryServices.DirectoryEntry] or a [PSCustomObject] imitation. Whatever was input, but with three extra properties added now.

dev:remarks.maml:para: The output object's default format is not modified so with default formatting it appears identical to the original. Upon closer inspection it now has SidString, Domain, and SamAccountName properties.

maml:description.maml:para: Convert a DirectoryEntry to a PSCustomObject

Recursively convert every property into a string, or a PSCustomObject (whose properties are all strings, or more PSCustomObjects) This obfuscates the troublesome PropertyCollection and PropertyValueCollection and Hashtable aspects of working with ADSI
DirectoryEntry objects to convert to PSCustomObjects
DirectoryEntry objects to convert to PSCustomObjects

dev:remarks.maml:para: Converts the DirectoryEntry for the local Administrator account into a PowerShell custom object with simplified property values. This makes it easier to work with the object in PowerShell and avoids the complexity of DirectoryEntry property collections, which can be difficult to access and manipulate directly.

maml:description.maml:para: Convert a PropertyValueCollection to a string
Useful when working with System.DirectoryServices and some other namespaces
This PropertyValueCollection will be converted to a string
This PropertyValueCollection will be converted to a string

dev:type.maml:name: None. Pipeline input is not accepted.
Returns a string representation of the PropertyValueCollection's value.

dev:remarks.maml:para: For each property in a DirectoryEntry, convert its corresponding PropertyValueCollection to a string

maml:description.maml:para: Use ADSI to collect more information about the IdentityReference in NTFS Access Control Entries
Recursively retrieves group members and detailed information about them Use caching to reduce duplicate directory queries
The NTFS AccessControlEntry object(s), grouped by their IdentityReference property TODO: Use System.Security.Principal.NTAccount instead
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
Properties of each Account to display on the report
Do not get group members
Properties of each Account to display on the report
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
The NTFS AccessControlEntry object(s), grouped by their IdentityReference property TODO: Use System.Security.Principal.NTAccount instead
Do not get group members

dev:type.maml:name: [System.Object] The input object is returned with additional properties added:
Members (if the DirectoryEntry is a group).

dev:remarks.maml:para: Incomplete example but it shows the chain of functions to generate the expected input for this function. This example gets the ACL for an important folder, resolves each identity reference in the access entries, groups them by the resolved identity reference, and then converts each unique identity to a detailed principal object. This provides comprehensive information about each security principal including their directory entry, domain information, and group membership details, which is essential for thorough permission analysis and reporting.

maml:description.maml:para: Convert a ResultPropertyValueCollection to a string
Useful when working with System.DirectoryServices and some other namespaces
ResultPropertyValueCollection object to convert to a string
ResultPropertyValueCollection object to convert to a string

dev:remarks.maml:para: For each property in a DirectoryEntry, convert its corresponding PropertyValueCollection to a string

maml:description.maml:para: Convert a SearchResult to a PSCustomObject

Recursively convert every property into a string, or a PSCustomObject (whose properties are all strings, or more PSCustomObjects) This obfuscates the troublesome ResultPropertyCollection and ResultPropertyValueCollection and Hashtable aspects of working with ADSI searches
SearchResult objects to convert to PSCustomObjects
SearchResult objects to convert to PSCustomObjects

dev:type.maml:name: Accepts SearchResult objects from a directory search via the pipeline.
Returns PSCustomObject instances with simplified properties.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Performs a search in Active Directory for all user objects, then converts each SearchResult into a PSCustomObject with simplified properties. This makes it easier to work with the search results in PowerShell by flattening complex nested property collections into regular object properties.

command:details.command:verb: TODO: There is a faster way than Select
command:details.command:noun: Object, just need to dig into the default formatting of SearchResult to see how to get those properties

maml:description.maml:para: Converts a SID string to a DirectoryEntry object.

Attempts to resolve a security identifier (SID) string to its corresponding DirectoryEntry object by querying the directory service using the LDAP provider. This function is not currently in use by the Export-Permission module.
Security Identifier (SID) string to convert to a DirectoryEntry
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
Security Identifier (SID) string to convert to a DirectoryEntry

maml:alert.maml:para: This function is not currently in use by Export-Permission

dev:remarks.maml:para: Attempts to convert a SID string representing a user or group to its corresponding DirectoryEntry object by searching Active Directory using the LDAP provider. This allows you to obtain detailed information about a security principal when you only have its SID string representation.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Resolves the NetBIOS domain name 'CONTOSO' to its distinguished name format 'DC=ad,DC=contoso,DC=com'. This conversion is necessary when constructing LDAP queries that require the domain in distinguished name format, particularly when working with Active Directory objects across different domains or forests. The function utilizes Windows API calls to perform accurate name translation.

maml:description.maml:para: Converts a domain FQDN to its NetBIOS name.

Retrieves the NetBIOS name for a specified domain FQDN by checking the cache or querying the directory service. For LDAP providers, it retrieves domain information from the directory. For non-LDAP providers, it extracts the first part of the FQDN before the first period.
Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN) to convert to NetBIOS name
ADSI provider to use (LDAP or WinNT)
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
ADSI provider to use (LDAP or WinNT)
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN) to convert to NetBIOS name

dev:type.maml:name: None. Pipeline input is not accepted.
System.String. The NetBIOS name of the domain.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Converts the fully qualified domain name 'contoso.com' to its NetBIOS name by automatically determining the appropriate method based on available information. The function will check the cache first to avoid unnecessary directory queries.

Converts the fully qualified domain name 'contoso.com' to its NetBIOS name using the LDAP provider specifically, which provides more accurate results in an Active Directory environment by querying the domain controller directly.

maml:description.maml:para: Converts a domain DNS name to its corresponding SID string.

Retrieves the security identifier (SID) string for a specified domain DNS name using either cached values or by querying the directory service. It supports both LDAP and WinNT providers and can fall back to local server resolution methods when needed.
Domain DNS name to convert to the domain's SID
AdsiProvider (WinNT or LDAP) of the servers associated with the provided FQDNs or NetBIOS names
This parameter can be used to reduce calls to Find-AdsiProvider
Useful when that has been done already but the DomainsByFqdn and DomainsByNetbios caches have not been updated yet
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
AdsiProvider (WinNT or LDAP) of the servers associated with the provided FQDNs or NetBIOS names
This parameter can be used to reduce calls to Find-AdsiProvider
Useful when that has been done already but the DomainsByFqdn and DomainsByNetbios caches have not been updated yet
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
Domain DNS name to convert to the domain's SID

dev:type.maml:name: None. Pipeline input is not accepted.
System.String. The SID string of the specified domain.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Converts the DNS domain name 'contoso.com' to its corresponding domain SID string by automatically determining the best ADSI provider to use and utilizing the cache to avoid redundant directory queries.

Converts the DNS domain name 'contoso.com' to its corresponding domain SID string by explicitly using the LDAP provider, which can be more efficient when you already know the appropriate provider to use.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a fake DirectoryEntry object for security principals that don't have objects in the directory.

Used in place of a DirectoryEntry for certain WinNT security principals that do not have objects in the directory. The WinNT provider only throws an error if you try to retrieve certain accounts/identities. This function creates a PSCustomObject that mimics a DirectoryEntry with the necessary properties.
Full directory path for the fake entry in the format "Provider://Domain/Name"
Security Identifier (SID) string for the fake entry
Description of the security principal
Schema class name (e.g., 'user', 'group', 'computer')
Optional input object containing additional properties to include in the fake directory entry

command:parameter.maml:name: NameAllowList

maml:description.maml:para: Account names known to be impossible to resolve to a Directory Entry (currently based on testing on a non-domain-joined PC)

command:parameter.dev:defaultValue: @{ 'ALL APPLICATION PACKAGES' = $null ; 'ALL RESTRICTED APPLICATION PACKAGES' = $null ; 'ANONYMOUS LOGON' = $null ; 'Authenticated Users' = $null ; 'BATCH' = $null ; 'BUILTIN' = $null ; 'CREATOR GROUP' = $null ; 'CREATOR GROUP SERVER' = $null ; 'CREATOR OWNER' = $null ; 'CREATOR OWNER SERVER' = $null ; 'DIALUP' = $null ; 'ENTERPRISE DOMAIN CONTROLLERS' = $null ; 'Everyone' = $null ; 'INTERACTIVE' = $null ; 'internetExplorer' = $null ; 'IUSR' = $null ; 'LOCAL' = $null ; 'LOCAL SERVICE' = $null ; 'NETWORK' = $null ; 'NETWORK SERVICE' = $null ; 'OWNER RIGHTS' = $null ; 'PROXY' = $null ; 'RDS Endpoint Servers' = $null ; 'RDS Management Servers' = $null ; 'RDS Remote Access Servers' = $null ; 'REMOTE INTERACTIVE LOGON' = $null ; 'RESTRICTED' = $null ; 'SELF' = $null ; 'SERVICE' = $null ; 'SYSTEM' = $null ; 'TERMINAL SERVER USER' = $null }

command:parameter.maml:name: NameBlockList

maml:description.maml:para: These are retrievable via the WinNT ADSI Provider which enables group member retrival so we don't want to return fake directory entries

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a fake DirectoryEntry object for the well-known "Everyone" security principal with the SID "S-1-1-0", which can be used for permission analysis when a real DirectoryEntry object cannot be retrieved.

maml:description.maml:para: Convert a domain distinguishedName name or NetBIOS name to its FQDN

For the DistinguishedName parameter, uses PowerShell's -replace operator to perform the conversion For the NetBIOS parameter, uses ConvertTo-DistinguishedName to convert from NetBIOS to distinguishedName, then recursively calls this function to get the FQDN
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk

dev:remarks.maml:para: Converts the domain distinguishedName 'DC=ad,DC=contoso,DC=com' to its FQDN format 'ad.contoso.com'. This is essential when working with LDAP directory paths that need to be converted to readable domain names or when constructing proper LDAP paths that require the FQDN of the domain for remote connections.

dev:type.maml:name: [System.DirectoryServices.DirectoryEntry] Returned with member info added now (if the DirectoryEntry is a group).

dev:remarks.maml:para: Retrieves the members of the local Administrators group and then expands each member with additional information such as SID and domain information. Foreign security principals from trusted domains are resolved to their actual DirectoryEntry objects from the appropriate domain.

Retrieves the members of the domain Administrators group and then expands each member with additional information such as SID and domain information. Foreign security principals from trusted domains are resolved to their actual DirectoryEntry objects from the appropriate domain.

Recursively retrieves group members and detailed information about them
Expecting a DirectoryEntry from the WinNT provider, or a PSObject imitation from Get-DirectoryEntry

dev:type.maml:name: [System.DirectoryServices.DirectoryEntry] Returned with member info added now (if the DirectoryEntry is a group).

dev:remarks.maml:para: Retrieves the members of the local Administrators group and then expands each member by adding additional information such as SID, domain information, and group membership details if the member is itself a group. This provides a complete hierarchical view of permissions.

maml:description.maml:para: Finds the SID prefix of the local server by querying the built-in administrator account.

This function queries the local computer or a remote computer via CIM to find the SID of the built-in administrator account (RID 500), then extracts and returns the server's SID prefix by removing the RID portion. This is useful for identifying the server's unique domain identifier in Active Directory environments.
Name of the computer to query via CIM
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
Name of the computer to query via CIM

dev:type.maml:name: None. Pipeline input is not accepted.
Returns the SID prefix of the specified computer or local computer.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Retrieves the SID prefix for the computer "DC01" by querying the built-in Administrator account and removing the RID portion. This domain SID prefix can be used to identify the domain and construct SIDs for domain users and groups.

maml:description.maml:para: Get the directory entries for a group and its members using ADSI
Uses the ADSI components to search a directory for a group, then get its members Both the WinNT and LDAP providers are supported
Path to the directory object to retrieve Defaults to the root of the current domain
Name (CN or Common Name) of the group to retrieve
Properties of the group members to retrieve
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
Path to the directory object to retrieve Defaults to the root of the current domain
Name (CN or Common Name) of the group to retrieve
Properties of the group members to retrieve

dev:type.maml:name: None. Pipeline input is not accepted.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Retrieves the local Administrators group from the specified computer using the WinNT provider, and returns all member accounts as DirectoryEntry objects. This allows for complete analysis of local group memberships including nested groups and domain accounts that have been added to local groups.

On a domain-joined computer, retrieves the domain's Administrators group and all of its members. On a workgroup computer, retrieves the local Administrators group and its members. This automatic detection simplifies scripts that need to work in both domain and workgroup environments.

maml:description.maml:para: Get members of a group from the LDAP provider
Use ADSI to get members of a group from the LDAP provider Return the group's DirectoryEntry plus a FullMembers property containing the member DirectoryEntries
Directory entry of the LDAP group whose members to get
Properties of the group members to find in the directory

dev:remarks.maml:para: Retrieves all members of the domain's Administrators group, including both direct members and those who inherit membership through their primary group. The function returns the original group DirectoryEntry object with an added FullMembers property containing all member DirectoryEntry objects. This approach ensures proper resolution of all group memberships regardless of how they are assigned.

maml:description.maml:para: Get information about a directory server including the ADSI provider it hosts and its well-known SIDs
Uses the ADSI provider to query the server using LDAP first, then WinNT upon failure Uses WinRM to query the CIM class Win32_SystemAccount for well-known SIDs
IP address or hostname of the directory server whose ADSI provider type to determine
NetBIOS name of the ADSI server whose information to determine
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
Remove the CIM session used to get ADSI server information

dev:remarks.maml:para: Retrieves information about the local computer's directory service, determining whether it uses the LDAP or WinNT provider, and collects information about well-known security identifiers (SIDs). This is essential for consistent identity resolution on the local system when analyzing permissions.

Connects to the domain controller for 'ad.contoso.com', determines it uses the LDAP provider, and retrieves domain-specific information including SIDs, NetBIOS name, and distinguished name. This enables proper identity resolution for domain accounts when working with permissions across systems.

Works only on domain-joined systems, otherwise returns nothing

dev:type.maml:name: None. Pipeline input is not accepted.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Retrieves the current domain of the computer running the script as a DirectoryEntry object. On domain-joined systems, this returns the Active Directory domain. On workgroup computers, it returns the local computer as the domain. The function caches the result to improve performance in subsequent operations involving the current domain.

Retrieve a directory entry using either the WinNT or LDAP provider for ADSI

In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
Credentials to use to bind to the directory Defaults to the credentials of the current user
Path to the directory object to retrieve Defaults to the root of the current domain
Properties of the target object to retrieve
Mapping of SID types to descriptions used for converting security identifiers

dev:type.maml:name: None. Pipeline input is not accepted.
[PSCustomObject] for security principals with no directory entry

dev:remarks.maml:para: As the current user on a domain-joined computer, bind to the current domain and retrieve the DirectoryEntry for the root of the domain
As the current user on a workgroup computer, bind to the local system and retrieve the DirectoryEntry for the root of the directory

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a hashtable of well-known SIDs indexed by their NT Account names (captions).

This function takes a hashtable of well-known SIDs (indexed by SID) and transforms it into a new hashtable where the keys are the NT Account names (captions) of the SIDs. This makes it easier to look up SID information when you have the account name representation rather than the SID itself.
Hashtable of well-known Security Identifiers (SIDs) with their properties
Hashtable of well-known Security Identifiers (SIDs) with their properties

dev:type.maml:name: A hashtable containing SID strings as keys and information objects as values.
Returns a hashtable with NT Account names as keys and SID information objects as values.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a hashtable of well-known SIDs indexed by their NT Account names and retrieves information about the SYSTEM account. This is useful when you need to look up SID information by NT Account name rather than by SID string.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves information about well-known security identifiers (SIDs).

Gets information about well-known security identifiers (SIDs) based on patterns and common formats. Uses Microsoft documentation references for SID information: - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/openspecs/windows_protocols/ms-dtyp/81d92bba-d22b-4a8c-908a-554ab29148ab
- https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/identity/ad-ds/manage/understand-security-identifiers
Security Identifier (SID) string to retrieve information for
Security Identifier (SID) string to retrieve information for

dev:type.maml:name: A SID string that identifies a well-known security principal.
PSCustomObject with properties such as Description, DisplayName, Name, NTAccount, SamAccountName, SchemaClassName, and SID.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns information about the built-in Administrators group.
Returns information about the Local System account.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a hashtable of well-known SIDs indexed by their friendly names.

This function takes a hashtable of well-known SIDs (indexed by SID) and transforms it into a new hashtable where the keys are the friendly names of the SIDs. This makes it easier to look up SID information when you know the name but not the SID itself.
Hashtable containing well-known SIDs as keys with their properties as values
Hashtable containing well-known SIDs as keys with their properties as values

dev:type.maml:name: A hashtable containing SID strings as keys and information objects as values.
Returns a hashtable with friendly names as keys and SID information objects as values.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a hashtable of well-known SIDs indexed by their friendly names and retrieves information about the Administrators group. This is useful when you need to look up SID information by name rather than by SID string.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns a hashtable of known security identifiers (SIDs) with detailed information.

Returns a hashtable of known SIDs which can be used to avoid errors and delays due to unnecessary directory queries. Some SIDs cannot be translated using the [SecurityIdentifier]::Translate or [NTAccount]::Translate methods. Some SIDs cannot be retrieved using CIM or ADSI. Hardcoding them here allows avoiding queries that we know will fail. Hardcoding them also improves performance by avoiding unnecessary directory queries with predictable results.

dev:type.maml:name: None. This function does not accept pipeline input.
System.Collections.Hashtable. Contains SIDs as keys and PSCustomObjects with SID information as values.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This hashtable can be used to look up information about well-known SIDs: $knownSids['S-1-5-18'].DisplayName # Returns 'LocalSystem' $knownSids['S-1-5-32-544'].Description # Returns description of the Administrators group

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the DNS name of the parent domain for a given computer or domain.

This function retrieves the DNS name of the parent domain for a specified domain or computer using CIM queries. For workgroup computers or when no parent domain is found, it falls back to using the primary DNS suffix from the client's global DNS settings. The function uses caching to improve performance during repeated calls.
NetBIOS name of the domain whose parent domain DNS to return
Existing CIM session to the computer (to avoid creating redundant CIM sessions)
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
Switch to remove the CIM session when done
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
Existing CIM session to the computer (to avoid creating redundant CIM sessions)
NetBIOS name of the domain whose parent domain DNS to return
Switch to remove the CIM session when done

dev:remarks.maml:para: Remark: This example retrieves the parent domain DNS name for a domain controller named "CORPDC01". The function will first attempt to get the domain information via CIM queries to the specified computer. Results are stored in the $Cache variable to improve performance if the function is called again with the same parameters. For domain controllers, this will typically return the forest root domain name.

maml:description.maml:para: Returns a dictionary of trusted domains by the current computer

Works only on domain-joined systems Use nltest to get the domain trust relationships for the domain of the current computer Use ADSI's LDAP provider to get each trusted domain's DNS name, NETBIOS name, and SID For each trusted domain the key is the domain's SID, or its NETBIOS name if the -KeyByNetbios switch parameter was used For each trusted domain the value contains the details retrieved with ADSI
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk

dev:type.maml:name: None. Pipeline input is not accepted.
[PSCustomObject] One object per trusted domain, each with a DomainFqdn property and a DomainNetbios property

dev:remarks.maml:para: Retrieves information about all domains trusted by the current domain-joined computer, including each domain's NetBIOS name, DNS name, and distinguished name. This information is essential for cross-domain identity resolution and permission analysis. The function stores the results in the provided cache to improve performance in subsequent operations involving these trusted domains.

maml:description.maml:para: Get members of a group from the WinNT provider
Get members of a group from the WinNT provider Convert them from COM objects into usable DirectoryEntry objects
DirectoryEntry [System.DirectoryServices.DirectoryEntry] of the WinNT group whose members to get
Properties of the group members to find in the directory
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
DirectoryEntry [System.DirectoryServices.DirectoryEntry] of the WinNT group whose members to get
Properties of the group members to find in the directory

dev:remarks.maml:para: Retrieves all members of the local Administrators group and returns them as DirectoryEntry objects. This allows for further processing of group membership information, including nested groups, and provides a consistent object format that works well with other ADSI functions. The Cache parameter ensures efficient operation by avoiding redundant directory queries.

maml:description.maml:para: Invoke a member method of a ComObject [__ComObject]

Use the InvokeMember method to invoke the InvokeMethod or GetProperty or SetProperty methods By default, invokes the GetProperty method for the specified Property If the Value parameter is specified, invokes the SetProperty method for the specified Property If the Method switch is specified, invokes the InvokeMethod method
The ComObject whose member method to invoke
The property to use with the invoked method
The value to set with the SetProperty method, or the name of the method to run with the InvokeMethod method
Use the InvokeMethod method of the ComObject
The ComObject whose member method to invoke
Use the InvokeMethod method of the ComObject
The property to use with the invoked method
The value to set with the SetProperty method, or the name of the method to run with the InvokeMethod method

dev:type.maml:name: None. Pipeline input is not accepted.
The output of the invoked method is returned directly

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get the first member of the local Administrators group on the current computer Then use Invoke-ComObject to invoke the GetProperty method and return the value of the AdsPath property This technique is essential when working with ADSI objects that expose properties or methods only through COM interfaces, providing a consistent way to access these properties in PowerShell.

maml:description.maml:para: Use CIM and ADSI to lookup info about IdentityReferences from Access Control Entries that came from Discretionary Access Control Lists

Based on the IdentityReference proprety of each Access Control Entry: Resolve SID to NT account name and vise-versa Resolve well-known SIDs Resolve generic defaults like 'NT AUTHORITY' and 'BUILTIN' to the applicable computer or domain name
IdentityReference from an Access Control Entry Expecting either a SID (S-1-5-18) or an NT account name (CONTOSO\User)
Object from Get-AdsiServer representing the directory server and its attributes
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
Properties of each Account to display on the report
Properties of each Account to display on the report
Object from Get-AdsiServer representing the directory server and its attributes
In-process cache to reduce calls to other processes or to disk
IdentityReference from an Access Control Entry Expecting either a SID (S-1-5-18) or an NT account name (CONTOSO\User)

dev:type.maml:name: None. Pipeline input is not accepted.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Resolves the local Administrator account on the BUILTIN domain to its proper SID, NetBIOS name, and DNS name format. This is useful when analyzing permissions to ensure consistency in how identities are represented, especially when comparing permissions across different systems or domains.

maml:description.maml:para: Resolves Windows service names to their corresponding security identifiers (SIDs).

This function takes service objects (from Get-Service or Win32_Service) and calculates their corresponding SIDs using the same algorithm as sc.exe showsid. It enriches the input service objects with SID and Status and returns the enhanced objects with all original properties preserved.
Output of Get-Service or an instance of the Win32_Service CIM class
Output of Get-Service or an instance of the Win32_Service CIM class

dev:remarks.maml:para: Remark: This example retrieves the Background Intelligent Transfer Service and resolves its service name to a SID. The output includes all original properties of the service plus the SID property.

maml:description.maml:para: Use Active Directory Service Interfaces to search an LDAP directory

Find directory entries using the LDAP provider for ADSI (the WinNT provider does not support searching) Provides a wrapper around the [System.DirectoryServices.DirectorySearcher] class Supports filtering, paging, and customizing which properties to return.
Path to the directory object to retrieve Defaults to the root of the current domain
Filter for the LDAP search

Search scope (Base, OneLevel, or Subtree)

dev:type.maml:name: None. Pipeline input is not accepted.
System.DirectoryServices.SearchResult collection representing the matching directory objects.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Searches the contoso.com domain for all user objects, retrieving results in pages of 1000 objects at a time. This is useful for efficiently retrieving large sets of directory objects without overwhelming memory resources.
